fullName: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace National Historical Park
description: For over a century people from around the world have come to rural Central Kentucky to honor the humble beginnings of our 16th president, Abraham Lincoln. His early life on Kentucky's frontier shaped his character and prepared him to lead the nation through Civil War. The country's first memorial to Lincoln, built with donations from young and old, enshrines the symbolic birthplace cabin.

images.title: The Memorial Building with fall colors
images.altText: The Memorial Building surrounded by fall colors
images.caption: Over 200,000 people a year come to walk up the steps of the Memorial Building to visit the site where Abraham Lincoln was born

images.title: The Memorial Building
images.altText: The first memorial erected to honor Abraham Lincoln
images.caption: The Memorial Building constructed on the traditional site of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.

images.title: The Symbolic Birth Cabin of Abraham Lincoln
images.altText: The symbolic birth cabin on the traditional site of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.
images.caption: The symbolic birth cabin of Abraham Lincoln.

images.title: Statue of the Lincoln Family in the Visitor Center
images.altText: Statue of the Lincoln family in the park's Visitor Center
images.caption: Visitors to the park can view the statue of the Lincoln family.

description: Acadia National Park protects the natural beauty of the highest rocky headlands along the Atlantic coastline of the United States, an abundance of habitats, and a rich cultural heritage. At 3.5 million visits a year, it's one of the top 10 most-visited national parks in the United States. Visitors enjoy 27 miles of historic motor roads, 158 miles of hiking trails, and 45 miles of carriage roads.

images.title: Sunset atop Cadillac Mountain
images.altText: A brilliant sunset filled with hues of blue, red, orange, magenta, and purple highlight the sky.
images.caption: As the tallest point on the eastern seaboard Cadillac Mountain provides fantastic viewpoints.

images.title: Acadia's rocky coastline
images.altText: Large puffy clouds dot a brilliant blue sky as wave crash against the rocky coastline of Acadia.
images.caption: Millions of people come to Acadia for our distinctive rocky coastline.

images.title: Climbing The Precipice
images.altText: Two hikers ascend a sheer cliff trail by way of historic iron rung ladders.
images.caption: Whether it's a stroll along Ocean Path or a difficult ascent up The Precipice, there are hiking trails for everyone!

images.title: Heavy snow-laden trees
images.altText: Hiking tracks carved through three feet of snow wind through a heavy snow-laden forest.
images.caption: During the colder months snows transform our landscape into a winter wonderland.

images.title: Starviewing
images.altText: A man peers into a telescope as the Milky Way lights up the night sky.
images.caption: With dark skies, Acadia is a fantastic place to come see the stars.

description: From the sweet little farm at the foot of Penn’s Hill to the gentleman’s country estate at Peace field, Adams National Historical Park is the story of “heroes, statesman, philosophers … and learned women” whose ideas and actions helped to transform thirteen disparate colonies into one united nation.

images.title: The John and John Quincy Adams Birthplaces
images.altText: The Birthplaces of Presidents John Adams (right) and John Quincy Adams (left)
images.caption: The Birthplaces of John and John Quincy Adams sit right next  to each other on Franklin Street.

images.title: The Birthplace of John Adams
images.altText: The Birthplace of John Adams
images.caption: The house where President John Adams was born in 1735.

images.title: The Birthplace of John Quincy Adams
images.altText: The Birthplace of John Quincy Adams
images.caption: The house where President John Quincy Adams was born in 1767.

images.title: Old House at Peace field
images.altText: A view of Old House at Peace field
images.caption: Old House at Peace field, where four generations of the Adams family lived from 1788 to 1927.

images.title: The Paneled Room
images.altText: The Paneled Room located inside Old House at Peace field.
images.caption: The Paneled Room greets everyone who enters Old House at Peace field.

images.title: The Stone Library
images.altText: The Stone Library located outside Old House at Peace field.
images.caption: The Stone Library houses up to 14,000 books belonging to the Adams family.

images.title: Inside the Stone Library
images.altText: Inside the Stone Library
images.caption: A view into the Stone Library

images.title: The Gardens Located at Old House at Peace field
images.altText: The gardens located at Old House at Peace field.
images.caption: The gardens located by Old House at Peace field bloom in every color you can imagine.

description: Over 200,000 African-American soldiers and sailors served in the U.S. Army and Navy during the Civil War. Their service helped to end the war and free over four million slaves. The African American Civil War Memorial honors their service and sacrifice.

images.title: African American Civil War Statue
images.altText: Site Statue
images.caption: A poignant reminder of our nations past

images.title: African American Sailor
images.altText: African American Sailor Close up
images.caption: African American Civil War Sailor

images.title: African American Soldier
images.altText: African American Soldier Close up
images.caption: African American Civil War Soldier

description: African Burial Ground is the oldest and largest known excavated burial ground in North America for both free and enslaved Africans. It protects the historic role slavery played in building New York

images.title: African Burial Ground Memorial
images.altText: African Burial Ground Memorial
images.caption: African Burial Ground Memorial

images.title: Visitor Center Entrance
images.altText: Entrance to visitor center with four banners above doorway.
images.caption: Entrance to the African Burial Ground National Monument visitor center.

images.title: Outdoor Memorial Entrance
images.altText: Outdoor memorial entrance with closed gate.
images.caption: Outdoor memorial entrance with closed gate.

images.title: Memorial's circle of diaspora.

images.caption: Memorial's circle of diaspora.

images.title: Exhibits within visitor center.

description: During the 1890s, scientists rediscovered what the Lakota Sioux already knew—bones preserved in one of the world's most significant Miocene Epoch mammal sites. Yet, this place called "Agate" is a landscape that reflects many influences—from early animals roaming the valleys and hills, to tribal nations calling the High Plains home, to explorers passing through or settling in the American West.

images.title: Visitor Center on the Prairie
images.altText: The visitor center sits in the middle of mixed grass prairie.
images.caption: From the Fossil Hills Trail the Visitor Center is a ship in a sea of prairie grasses.

images.title: The Agate Fossil Hills and Tipis
images.altText: Tipis and Fossil Hills represent the two subjects that Agate Fossil Beds interprets.
images.caption: One of the first impressions that visitors have are the tipis and the Fossil Hills.

images.title: A July Storm Passes
images.altText: Thunderheads are common in July.
images.caption: Summer storms include thunderheads and lightning and can be exciting and dangerous.

images.title: Dinohyus in the Visitor Center Fossil Diorama
images.altText: The Dinohyus was a scavenger, nicknamed "Terrible Pig"
images.caption: Visitors stare in wonder at the huge head of the "apex" predator of the plains some 20 million years ago.

images.title: The James H. Cook collection
images.altText: This buckskin shirt decorated with quills was worn by Red Cloud.
images.caption: Visitors agree that this shirt decorated with quillwork and worn by Red Cloud of the Oglala Lakota is a priceless piece of history.

description: Established in 2000 to preserve, protect and interpret traditional Native Hawaiian culture and natural resources, Ala Kahakai National Historic Trail is a 175 mile corridor encompassing a network of culturally and historically significant trails. This "trail by the sea" traverses wahi pana (storied landscapes), ancient Hawaiian sites and over 200 ahupuaʻa (traditional land divisions). Connect now!

images.title: Waiulaula Bay
images.altText: sandy beach
images.caption: Sandy beach after a storm

description: The headwaters of Alagnak Wild River lie within the rugged Aleutian Range of neighboring Katmai National Park and Preserve. Meandering west towards Bristol Bay and the Bering Sea, the Alagnak traverses the beautiful Alaska Peninsula, providing an unparalleled opportunity to experience the unique wilderness, wildlife, and cultural heritage of southwest Alaska.

images.title: salmon in Alagnak River
images.altText: underwater photo of salmon swimming in river
images.caption: Each summer, hundreds of thousands of salmon return to the Alagnak watershed to spawn.

images.title: Rafts along the river
images.altText: inflatable rafts on the edge of a river
images.caption: Rafting is a popular way to experience the river.

images.title: Alagnak Wild River
images.altText: aerial view of braided Alagnak River
images.caption: Alagnak River's lower reaches are extremely braided.

description: Alaska’s parks, forests, and refuges are rich and varied. The Anchorage Interagency Visitor Center helps visitors and residents to have meaningful, safe, enjoyable experiences on public lands, and encourages them to sustain the natural and cultural resources of Alaska. This center and three others statewide provide trip-planning, interpretation, and education for all ages.

images.title: Anchorage APLIC
images.altText: Front of the Anchorage Federal Building, housing the Anchorage APLIC
images.caption: The Anchorage APLIC is located inside the Federal Building

images.title: Fairbanks APLIC
images.altText: Fairbanks Alaska Public Lands Information Center, located inside the Morris Thompson Cultural & Visi
images.caption: Fairbanks Alaska Public Lands Information Center, located inside the Morris Thompson Cultural & Visitors Center, in summer

description: Alcatraz reveals stories of American incarceration, justice, and our common humanity. This small island was once a fort, a military prison, and a maximum security federal penitentiary. In 1969, the Indians of All Tribes occupied Alcatraz for 19 months in the name of freedom and Native American civil rights. We invite you to explore Alcatraz's complex history and natural beauty.

images.title: Mug Shot Camera
images.altText: Mugshot camera
images.caption: Mugshot camera used to record new inmates.

images.title: Alcatraz Rangers and Firetruck
images.altText: Alcatraz Rangers and Firetruck
images.caption: Alcatraz Rangers and 1934 Diamond T Firetruck

images.title: Inmate Fake Head Used in 1962 Escape
images.altText: Inmate Fake Head Used in 1962 Escape
images.caption: Inmate Fake Head Used in 1962 Escape

images.credit: NPS Photo - Golden Gate National Recreation Area, GOGA 2316a
images.title: Army Prisoners in the Stockade, 1902
images.altText: Army Prisoners in the Stockade, 1902
images.caption: Army Prisoners in the Stockade, 1902

images.title: Serving the Christmas Meal, c 1951
images.altText: Cook serving Christmas dinner with menu posted above.
images.caption: An inmate worker distributes trays near the steam table. Bars separate the kitchen from the mess hall.  The day’s menu, the Christmas meal, appears on a sign over his head. The menu includes consomme, stuffed celery, green olives and mixed sweet pickles,

fullName: Aleutian Islands World War II National Historic Area
description: During World War II the remote Aleutian Islands, home to the Unangax̂ (Aleut) people for over 8,000 years, became a fiercely contested battleground in the Pacific. This thousand-mile-long archipelago saw invasion by Japanese forces, the occupation of two islands; a mass relocation of Unangax̂ civilians; a 15-month air war; and one of the deadliest battles in the Pacific Theater.

images.title: A homeland changed
images.altText: Group of people around a Russian cross in tall grass
images.caption: In September 2009, Nick Lekanoff, Sr., former Makushin resident, traveled with his daughter and other descendants of Makushin on the Tiglax to visit the village site, which had been left behind in the evacuation of 1942 and never permanently resettled.

images.title: William C. House and the Aerological Detail on Kiska
images.altText: Twelve men and a dog pose for a photo
images.caption: After his aerological crew was captured by the Japanese in June, 1942, Senior Petty Officer William House survived 50 days in the hills of Kiska.  He ate grass, shellfish, and worms. Weighing 80lbs he surrendered and was respected for his perseverance.

images.title: Evacuation and internment
images.altText: People crowd at the railing of a ship
images.caption: Pribilof villagers, here lining the railing of the USAT Delarof on the day of their departure (June 15, 1942), were evacuated with only a few hours notice and no idea of their ultimate destination.

images.title: Challenging weather conditions
images.altText: Four men gather around a invalid man
images.caption: Soldiers rub the frostbitten feet of a disabled soldier. Over 2000 weather-related casualties—the majority Attu feet—were recorded for U.S. troops. This number represents the largest classification of casualties suffered by American forces on the island.

images.title: The battle for Attu Island
images.altText: Six men with guns carry a person on a stretcher in a valley.
images.caption: U.S. wounded are gathered from the battlefield on Attu Island.  The battle on Attu, lasting nearly 20 days, was the second most deadly in the Pacific Theater.

images.title: Cultural collision
images.altText: A uniformed man holds up a broken Russian cross
images.caption: The Aleutian campaign brought together Russian, Native Alaskan, Japanese, and Euroamerican cultures. During the war 7 historic churches were damaged or destroyed. Villages were unrecognizable or burned to the ground and personal belonging lost or stolen.

description: 13,000 years ago, this site was well-known by mammoth hunters as a source of flint for tools. Centuries passed but the colorful flint never lost its value and usefulness in the Texas Panhandle. Gain a sense of how integral this site was to the survival, commerce and culture of the High Plains. Visit Alibates Flint Quarries to see the many colors of the beautiful Alibates Flint.

images.title: Turtle Petroglyph
images.altText: Turtle Petroglyph at Antelope Creek Village Site
images.caption: Turtle Petroglyph at Antelope Creek Village Site

images.title: Alibates Visitor Center
images.altText: A view of the gardens and Alibates Visitor Center.
images.caption: The gardens and Alibates Visitor Center host activities and ranger-led programs throughout the year.

images.title: Alibates Flint
images.altText: Colorful chunks of Alibates Flint.
images.caption: Used for at least 13,000 years, Alibates Flint was the choice of many tribes for their stone tools, spearpoints and arrowheads.

images.title: Alibates Flint Quarries Trail
images.altText: Stair steps up the Alibates Flint Quarries Trail.
images.caption: Take a hike up the Quarries Trail to learn about this important stone.

images.title: Snowy Alibates
images.altText: A snowy mesa, as seen from the Alibates Visitor Center.
images.caption: Every season hold special beauty at Alibates Flint Quarries National Monument.

fullName: Allegheny Portage Railroad National Historic Site
description: The first railroad to circumvent the Allegheny Mountains, the Allegheny Portage Railroad was the finishing piece of the Pennsylvania Mainline Canal. "The Portage," opened in 1834, marking the first time that there was one, direct route between Philadelphia and Pittsburgh. All things to all people, it served merchants, passengers, slaves in pursuit of freedom, and soldiers from the Mexican War.

images.title: Lemon House
images.altText: Lemon House
images.caption: Lemon House, one of the historic structures in the park.

description: American Memorial Park honors the American and Marianas people who gave their lives during the Marianas Campaign of World War II. At the park, memorials stand in tribute to the courage and sacrifice of the US Servicemen and Chamorro and Carolinian civilians who were killed in the battles between the United States and Japan that took place on Saipan, Tinian, and the Philippine Sea in 1944.

images.title: Lawn at American Memorial Park
images.altText: Large lawn in front of the memorial.
images.caption: A popular place for visitors.

images.title: Ampitheater at American Memorial Park
images.altText: Rehearsing at the American Memorial Park ampitheater
images.caption: The ampitheater is where many performances take place.

images.title: Visitor Center at American Memorial Park
images.altText: The visitor center is open daily.
images.caption: The visitor center  is a popular place to learn about Saipan's role in WWII history.

images.title: Walking the path at American Memorial Park.
images.altText: People walking the paths at the American Memorial Park.
images.caption: The paths at the American Memorial Park are always in use.

images.title: The beach at American Memorial Park.
images.altText: Crystal clear blue swimming at the park.
images.caption: The beach is an inviting place to swim and relax.

description: An oasis in the desert, Amistad National Recreation Area consists of the US portion of the International Amistad Reservoir. Amistad, whose name comes from the Spanish word meaning friendship, is best known for excellent water-based recreation, camping, hiking, rock art viewing, and its rich cultural history. Amistad is also home to a wide variety of plant and animal life above and below the water.

images.title: View of Amistad National Recreation Area from The Diablo East Nature Trail
images.altText: Amistad National Recreation Area
images.caption: Blue skies and blue waters are common at Amistad National Recreation Area

images.title: Under the HWY 90 Bridge
images.altText: Under the HWY 90 Bridge
images.caption: A view of the Amistad Reservoir and the HWY 90 Bridge from Governors Landing.

images.title: The shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.altText: A view of the peaceful shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.caption: A peaceful view of the shores along Amistad National Recreation Area

images.title: Sunset over Amistad National Recreation Area
images.altText: Sunset over Amistad National Recreation Area
images.caption: The ever chainging and beautiful sunsets in Southwest Texas are one of the many things visitor enjoy while at Amistad National Recreation Area.

images.title: Limestone shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.altText: Limestone shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.caption: Limestone is visible along the shoreline of Amistad National Recreation Area.

description: Welcome to Anacostia Park, your neighborhood national park in the heart of Washington, DC! Enjoy exercise along the river trail or relax by the water, Anacostia Park is a breath of fresh air and a space to unwind amid a bustling city.

images.title: Anacostia Drive
images.altText: Aerial view of Anacostia Drive and the playground
images.caption: Anacostia Drive and the Anacostia river Trail run along side the Anacostia river. Views of the Navy Yard and Nats. Stadium can be seen as across the river.

description: The Camp Sumter military prison at Andersonville was one of the largest Confederate military prisons during the Civil War. During the 14 months the prison existed, more than 45,000 Union soldiers were confined here. Of these, almost 13,000 died here. Today, Andersonville National Historic Site is a memorial to all American prisoners of war throughout the nation's history.

images.title: Historic Site of Camp Sumter Civil War Military Prison at Andersonville
images.altText: A cannon sits out in front of a replica of part of the wooden stockade walls once at Andersonville
images.caption: Camp Sumter Military Prison, known as Andersonville, was the deadliest ground of the Civil War. Nearly 13,000 American soldiers died here.

images.title: Summer of 1865 at Andersonville Photo by A.J. Riddle
images.altText: A historic photo of thousands of emaciated Union soldiers held prisoner in 1865
images.caption: Over 32,000 Union soldiers languished at Andersonville in August 1865 when this photo was taken by A.J. Riddle.

images.title: Andersonville National Cemetery
images.altText: Fog rests on a stone monument of a Civil War soldier standing among hundreds of graves.
images.caption: The site where the nearly 13,000 Union soldiers who died at Andersonville, designated as a National Cemetery in 1865, is still an active cemetery. Nearly 21,000 American military veterans rest here in honor.

images.title: The Illinois Monument at Andersonville National Historic Site
images.altText: A large stone monument with 2 Civil War soldiers, a female figure, and 2 children.
images.caption: Many states honored their fallen sons with monuments placed at Andersonville National Historic Site.

images.title: National Prisoner of War Museum
images.altText: A military garrison cap with a small U.S. flag and silver bar in an exhibit case
images.caption: Andersonville is the only National Park Service site with the mission of preserving the stories of all American Prisoners of War throughout history.

description: Andrew Johnson's complex presidency (1865-69) illustrates the Constitution at work following the Civil War. As the President and Congress disagreed on Reconstruction methods, the Constitution served as their guide on balance of powers, vetoes, and impeachment. In the end, it evolved as a living document with pivotal amendments on freedom, citizenship, and voting rights - topics still vital today.

images.title: Andrew Johnson Homestead
images.altText: Andrew Johnson Homestead
images.caption: Home of the 17th President from 1851-1875

images.title: Early Home
images.altText: Andrew Johnson's Early Home
images.caption: The Johnson family home from the 1830s - 1851

images.title: Andrew Johnson Monument
images.altText: Andrew Johnson Monument
images.caption: Gravestone of President and Mrs. Andrew Johnson

description: Given its remote location and challenging weather conditions, Aniakchak is one of the most wild and least visited places in the National Park System. This landscape is a vibrant reminder of Alaska's location in the volcanically active "Ring of Fire," as it is home to an impressive six mile (10 km) wide, 2,500 ft (762 m) deep caldera formed during a massive volcanic eruption 3,500 years ago.

images.title: Floating the Gates of Aniakchak
images.altText: A lone raft floats the Aniakchak Wild River as it flows through the "Gates"
images.caption: A lone raft floats the Aniakchak Wild River as it flows through the "Gates"

images.title: Aniakchak Caldera
images.altText: Aerial shot of Aniakchak Caldera
images.caption: Aerial shot of Aniakchak Caldera

images.title: Black Nose, Aniakchak Caldera
images.altText: Black Nose, Aniakchak Caldera
images.caption: Black Nose, Aniakchak Caldera

images.caption: Maar Lake, Aniakchak Caldera

images.altText: The Gates of Aniakchak
images.caption: The Gates of Aniakchak

description: 23,000 soldiers were killed, wounded or missing after twelve hours of savage combat on September 17, 1862. The Battle of Antietam ended the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia's first invasion into the North and led Abraham Lincoln to issue the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation.

images.title: Antietam National Cemetery
images.altText: a monument of a soldier in the background with graves in front of the monument
images.caption: Private Soldier Monument at the cemetery

images.title: Fog Over the Battlefield
images.altText: fog filling in the low areas of the field at sunset
images.caption: View from the visitor center looking toward Bloody Lane at sunset

images.title: Monument at Sunset
images.altText: a monument of a soldier at sunset
images.caption: 130th Pennsylvania Monument at Bloody Lane

images.title: Cannon the Field
images.altText: artillery piece sitting on a rock break
images.caption: Artillery played a key role at Antietam.  Over 500 cannon were involved in the fighting.

images.title: Burnside Bridge
images.altText: three arch stone bridge over Antietam Creek
images.caption: Burnside Bridge in the snow from the Union side of Antietam Creek.

description: Imagine that moment, being in that perfect spot as the sun rises, and everything comes into focus. A rocky shoreline suddenly reflects the world around you. Waiting for you among the water, land, forests, and history is that moment. How will the islands inspire you?

images.title: View of the Bowl at the Mainland Sea Caves
images.altText: Tree-covered red cliffs meet greenish blue water, in a bowl shape.
images.caption: Hike or paddle to views of the sea caves along the mainland unit of the park.

images.title: Ice Caves
images.altText: Sunlight shines through a cave hole surrounded by icicles onto the frozen lake surface
images.caption: While infrequent, the unique beauty and temporal nature of these ice formations serves to make the mainland ice caves all the more memorable and desirable.

images.title: Raspberry Island Lighthouse
images.altText: A two story white house with a light tower in the middle, reflects the colors of the setting sun.
images.caption: Step into the past with a visit to Raspberry Island Lighthouse.

images.title: Julian Bay
images.altText: Sunrise illuminates a long beach near calm water.
images.caption: Julian Bay is a popular beach to visit on Stockton Island.

images.title: Rocky Shorelines
images.altText: A rocky shoreline meets the calm water of a lake at sunset.
images.caption: Experience the setting sun along a rocky island shoreline.

description: The Appalachian Trail is a 2,180+ mile long public footpath that traverses the scenic, wooded, pastoral, wild, and culturally resonant lands of the Appalachian Mountains. Conceived in 1921, built by private citizens, and completed in 1937, today the trail is managed by the National Park Service, US Forest Service, Appalachian Trail Conservancy, numerous state agencies and thousands of volunteers.

images.title: McAfee Knob
images.altText: Silhouette of a man with backpack standing on McAfee Knob at sunset with mountains in the distance.
images.caption: McAfee Knob is one of the most popular locations along the A.T. to take photographs.

images.title: Appalachian Trail
images.altText: The Appalachian Trail runs across a mountain ridge line with views to the horizon of mountain range.
images.caption: Crossing into thirteen states, hikers experience a variety of scenery along the way.

images.title: The Infamous White Blaze of the A.T.
images.altText: A white blaze marks a tree in the foreground, with a man and child walking away on the wooded trail.
images.caption: The white blaze marks the Appalachian Trail as a way for hikers to identify the route.

images.credit: Photo Credit: Maine Appalachian Trail Club
images.title: Volunteer on the A.T.
images.altText: A volunteer is carrying a split log while walking across a wooden footbridge in the woods.
images.caption: The Appalachian Trail is maintained largely by volunteers.

images.title: Winter on the A.T.
images.altText: A snowy winter view from the A.T. overlooking snowy mountains and clouds in the distance.
images.caption: Hikers can experience many seasons along the A.T. all year round. It is important to be prepared.

fullName: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
description: On April 9, 1865, the surrender of the Army of Northern Virginia in the McLean House in the village of Appomattox Court House, Virginia signaled the end of the nation's largest war. Two important questions about its future were answered. Could the nation survive a civil war intact, and would that nation exist without slavery? The answer to both was yes and a new nation was born.

images.title: The McLean House
images.altText: This is the home where Gen. Lee surrendered to Gen. Grant on April 9, 1865
images.caption: This is the home where Gen. Lee surrendered to Gen. Grant on April 9, 1865

images.title: The McLean House during the 150th Anniversary
images.altText: The McLean House during the 150th Anniversary with luminaries along the Stage Road.
images.caption: The McLean House during the 150th Anniversary with luminaries along the Stage Road.

images.credit: Photo by Cameron Davidson (permission for NPS use)
images.title: The village of Appomattox Court House
images.altText: Aerial view of the village of Appomattox Court House taken in 2014.
images.caption: Aerial view of the village of Appomattox Court House taken in 2014.

images.title: Living History at Appomattox Court House NHP
images.altText: Living History at Appomattox Court House NHP
images.caption: Living History at Appomattox Court House NHP

description: For millions of years, granite monadnocks have stood watch over the rivers and forests of Georgia. These breathtaking landscapes are the cornerstones of the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area, which serves to protect & promote these outcrops and the surrounding region as a recreational wonder and national treasure.

Visit Arches to discover a landscape of contrasting colors, land forms and textures unlike any other in the world. The park has over 2,000 natural stone arches, in addition to hundreds of soaring pinnacles, massive fins and giant balanced rocks. This red-rock wonderland will amaze you with its formations, refresh you with its trails, and inspire you with its sunsets.

images.title: The Organ with Potholes
images.altText: a stone monolith reflected in standing water
images.caption: The Organ rock formation is reflected in one of many natural potholes.

images.title: Double O Arch
images.altText: a broad, red arch with rock pinnacles in the background
images.caption: Double O Arch is one of many large arches in the Devils Garden area

images.title: Delicate Arch
images.altText: a stone arch
images.caption: Delicate Arch is perhaps the most famous natural arch in the world.

images.title: Milky Way over the Garden of Eden
images.altText: the Milky Way arcs above silhouetted stone pinnacles
images.caption: Arches offers some excellent night sky viewing.

images.title: Park Avenue Trail
images.altText: two hikers descend a broad wash with tall rock walls on either side.
images.caption: The Park Avenue trail is one of many hiking trails at Arches, ranging from easy to strenuous.

description: Located at the confluence of two rivers, Arkansas Post has served as a gathering place for many cultures throughout human history - it represents cultural cooperation, conflict, synthesis, and diversity.

images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.altText: confluence of two rivers
images.caption: Located at the confluence of two rivers, Arkansas Post has served as a gathering place for many cultures.

images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.altText: the Alligator Slough footbridge
images.caption: The Alligator Slough footbridge

images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.altText: Arkansas Post National Memorial is in the Lower Mississippi Riverine Forest ecoregion.
images.caption: Located at the confluence of two rivers, Arkansas Post has served as a gathering place for many cultures throughout human history - it represents cultural cooperation, conflict, synthesis, and diversity.

images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.altText: Over the three centuries of history at Arkansas Post, the area has been greatly changed by both natu
images.caption: Located at the northern edge of the Gulf coastal plain, the Arkansas Post's native growth ranges from prairie grasses and lowland hardwood forests to wetland marshes near the bayous and river.

images.title: Living History
images.altText: Arkansas Post National Monument cannon firing
images.caption: During the Civil War, Confederate troops tried to maintain tactical control of the confluence of the Arkansas and White Rivers, and in 1862 they constructed a massive earthen fortification known as Fort Hindman at the Post. In January 1863 Union troops d

fullName: Arlington House, The Robert E. Lee Memorial
description: Arlington House is the nation’s memorial to Robert E. Lee. It honors him for specific reasons, including his role in promoting peace and reunion after the Civil War. In a larger sense it exists as a place of study and contemplation of the meaning of some of the most difficult aspects of American History: military service; sacrifice; citizenship; duty; loyalty; slavery and freedom.

images.title: Arlington House
images.altText: Wreaths at Arlington Cemetery
images.caption: Arlington House, the Robert E. Lee Memorial

images.title: The Kitchen Garden
images.altText: Spring in the Garden
images.caption: The Kitchen Garden at Arlington House has been feeding people for over 200 years

images.title: The Tomb of the Civil War Unknown
images.altText: The Tomb of the Civil War Unknown
images.caption: The Tomb of the Civil War Unknown was established in Mrs. Lee's rose garden during the Civil War

images.title: The Custis- Lee Wedding
images.altText: The Custis- Lee Wedding
images.caption: Robert E. Lee and Mary Custis were married on June 30th, 1831.

images.title: Arlington House, the Robert E. Lee Memorial
images.altText: Two images of Arlington House from 1933
images.caption: Arlington House was transferred from the War Department to the National Park Service in 1933. On the same day many other parks in Virginia and the District of Columbia were placed under the jurisdiction of the National Park Service.

description: Want to live on the edge? Visit a place recreated each day by ocean wind and waves. Life on Assateague Island has adapted to an existence on the move. Explore sandy beaches, salt marshes, maritime forests and coastal bays. Rest, relax, recreate and enjoy some time on the edge of the continent.

images.title: Wild Horses on the dunes at Assateague
images.altText: Wild horses on the dunes at Assateague
images.caption: There are few places in the United States where you can view wild horses.Take advantage of the opportunity to view these horses in a natural habitat.

images.title: Wild horses grazing in the salt marshes on Assateague Island
images.altText: Horses grazing in the marsh at the water's edge.
images.caption: Assateague's wild horses can often be found grazing in salt marshes.

images.title: Tree Swallows Migrating along Assateague
images.altText: Tree Swallows migrating along the beach at Assateague
images.caption: Enormous flocks of migrating tree swallows stop and rest on Assateague beaches in the fall.

images.title: Camping at Assateague
images.altText: tents and vehicle in the oceanside campground dunes
images.caption: Tent camping in the Oceanside campground at Assateague is a great way to relax and recreate at the beach.

images.title: Waves on Assateague beach
images.altText: waves on Assateague beach with people fishing in the background
images.caption: Visit the shifting sands at the water's edge where thousands of waves change the beach every day.

description: Our country’s landscape is rich and mysterious. It is filled with twisting bayous, rivers and America’s largest river swamp. We have fields of sugar cane and cotton, ancient live oaks and towering cypress. Alligators, raccoons, and even bears roam our lands while 270 species of birds take to our skies. From our waters come catfish, shrimp, oysters and the crawfish that make us so well known.

images.title: Atchafalaya Basin
images.altText: Atchafalaya Basin
images.caption: Atchafalaya Basin

description: The Augusta Canal helped usher the Industrial Revolution into the American South. Built in 1845 as a source of power, water, and transportation, the canal today is the only fully intact American industrial canal in continuous operation. By 1847 the first mills opened, followed by the massive Civil War era Confederate Powder Works and many more industries in the later decades of the 19th century.

images.title: Petersburg Boat
images.altText: Petersburg Boat passes Sibley Mill and the chimney of Confederate States Powder Works along the Augu
images.caption: Petersburg Boat passes Sibley Mill and the chimney of Confederate States Powder Works along the Augusta Canal National Heritage Area

description: Pueblo people describe this site as part of their migration journey. Today you can follow their ancient passageways to a distant time. Explore a 900-year old ancestral Pueblo Great House of over 400 masonry rooms. Look up and see original timbers holding up the roof. Search for the fingerprints of ancient workers in the mortar. Listen for an echo of ritual drums in the reconstructed Great Kiva.

images.title: Great Kiva in Aztec West plaza
images.altText: Reconstructed stone kiva amidst stone ruins
images.caption: Great Kiva in Aztec West plaza

images.title: Great Kiva
images.altText: Interior of a reconstructed great kiva
images.caption: The reconstructed Great Kiva

images.title: Rainbow over the Great Kiva
images.altText: Rainbow over the reconstructed Great Kiva
images.caption: Rainbow over the reconstructed Great Kiva

images.title: Winter snow on Aztec West great house
images.altText: Winter snow on stone ruins
images.caption: Winter snow on Aztec West great house

images.title: T-shaped doorway in Aztec West

images.caption: Original "T-shaped" doorway in Aztec West

images.title: Original ancestral Pueblo roof structure
images.altText: Three layers of original intact roof beams
images.caption: Original ancestral Pueblo roof structures

description: The rugged beauty of the Badlands draws visitors from around the world. These striking geologic deposits contain one of the world’s richest fossil beds. Ancient horses and rhinos once roamed here. The park’s 244,000 acres protect an expanse of mixed-grass prairie where bison, bighorn sheep, prairie dogs, and black-footed ferrets live today.

images.title: Badlands Rugged Peaks
images.altText: Badlands formations are very rugged and often have sharp peaks.
images.caption: Badlands formations are very rugged and often have sharp peaks.

images.title: Badlands Yellow Mounds
images.altText: The yellow mounds are peaking out of the formations in this photo.
images.caption: The yellow mounds are peaking out of the formations in this photo.

images.title: Badlands Storm
images.altText: The yellow mounds are peaking out of the formations in this photo.
images.caption: The yellow mounds are peaking out of the formations in this photo.

images.title: Clover Landscape

images.caption: The park has seasonal changes in colors so plan ahead!

images.title: Badlands in the Winter
images.altText: road leading between snow covered badlands formations
images.caption: Winter in Badlands National Park often creates snow covered wonderlands throughout the park.

description: For nearly three centuries, Baltimore has stood as a center of commerce and culture for the Chesapeake Bay. The city has seen the incredible transformation of American identity, shaped by war, prosperity, and struggles for freedom and civil rights. Visit the Baltimore National Heritage Area to experience the places and people that shaped the nation and forged the American identity.

images.title: Baltimore National Heritage Area
images.altText: Washington Monument, Baltimore
images.caption: Washington Monument, Baltimore

description: This 29-mile highway connects Baltimore, MD and Washington, D.C. The parkway has carried visitors to and from the capital city since 1954.

images.caption: The parkway is dedicated for Gladys Noon Spellman

images.title: Baltimore Washington Parkway

images.caption: Millions enjoy the scenic entryway to the Nation's Capital

images.altText: Baltimore Washington Parkway
images.caption: Baltimore Washington Parkway

description: Bandelier National Monument protects over 33,000 acres of rugged but beautiful canyon and mesa country as well as evidence of a human presence here going back over 11,000 years. Petroglyphs, dwellings carved into the soft rock cliffs, and standing masonry walls pay tribute to the early days of a culture that still survives in the surrounding communities.

images.altText: the village of Tyuonyi
images.caption: A view of Tyuonyi and the cliff dwelling in Frijoles Canyon from the mesa.

description: Home to the National Woman's Party for more than 90 years, this was the epicenter of the struggle for women's rights. From this house in the shadow of the U.S. Capitol and Supreme Court, Alice Paul and the NWP developed innovative strategies and tactics to advocate for the Equal Rights Amendment and equality for women. President Barack Obama designated the national monument on April 12, 2016.

images.title: Belmont-Paul Women's Equality NM House
images.altText: Belmont-Paul Women's Equality NM House
images.caption: 411th Unit of the National Park Service

images.caption: Entry way beauty

images.caption: A moment of repose

images.caption: To write a letter...

fullName: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site
description: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site features a reconstructed 1840s adobe fur trading post on the mountain branch of the Santa Fe Trail where traders, trappers, travelers, and the Cheyenne and Arapaho tribes came together in peaceful terms for trade. Today, living historians recreate the sights, sounds, and smells of the past with guided tours, demonstrations and special events.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort with shortgrass prairie in foreground and blue sky and clouds above
images.caption: Bent's Old Fort was the only permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and Santa Fe.

images.title: Fur trapper explains the work of the 1830s.
images.altText: Fur trapper in camp
images.caption: Special events bring the past alive with encampments, fort trade and Plains Indian life.

images.title: A Lakota warrior barters with the traders in the fort plaza
images.altText: Plains Indian trade in plaza
images.caption: Trade with a Lakota warrior for trade goods from around the world.

images.title: Hiking the Santa Fe Trail
images.altText: HIkers follow behind the fort's wagon on the Santa Fe Trail
images.caption: The Santa Fe Trail Encampment features a hike with the fort's wagon down the original Santa Fe Trail.

images.title: Open hearth cooking in the fort kitchen
images.altText: Cooking in fort kitchen
images.caption: Buffalo meat is broil in the reflector oven for the fort employees as was done in the 1840s.

images.title: Swivel cannon is fired using 18th century drill
images.altText: Swivel cannon firing
images.caption: The fort's security depended on its ability to resist attack.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort with shortgrass prairie, tepee and wagon in foreground and blue sky & clouds above
images.caption: Bent's Old Fort was the only permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and Santa Fe.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort in background with wagon in front; fall yellow cottonwood leaves in foreground
images.caption: Bent's Old Fort was the only permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and Santa Fe.

images.title: Santa Fe Trail Encampment and Trail Hike
images.altText: Interpreters and volunteers in period clothing on horseback and in wagons; group of people standing
images.caption: The Park features the Santa Fe Trail Encampment during the Centennial. Over 40 historical interpreters bring the fort to life. Visitors can hike 3 miles down the original Santa Fe Trail with the fort's wagons.

description: Bering Land Bridge National Preserve lies at the continental crossroads that greatly influenced the distribution of life in the Western Hemisphere during the Pleistocene Epoch. It is a vital landscape for indigenous communities who depend on the land just as their ancestors did for many generations. It is a wild and ecologically healthy landscape unlike any other.

images.title: Flock of shore birds
images.altText: Flock of shore birds taking flight
images.caption: Flock of shore birds taking flight

images.title: Fall Colors
images.altText: A hiker is seen in the distance as autumn colors dominate the tundra landscape.
images.caption: Autumn hike at Bering Land Bridge

images.caption: Three wet muskox.

images.altText: Rolling sand dunes with sparse vegetation with full moon rising above.
images.caption: Coastal moon rise

description: There is a place in Far West Texas where night skies are dark as coal and rivers carve temple-like canyons in ancient limestone. Here, at the end of the road, hundreds of bird species take refuge in a solitary mountain range surrounded by weather-beaten desert. Tenacious cactus bloom in sublime southwestern sun, and diversity of species is the best in the country. This magical place is Big Bend...

images.title: Desert Scenery
images.altText: Desert Scenery
images.caption: Big Bend is a prime example of Chihuahuan Desert

description: The freshwaters of the Big Cypress Swamp, essential to the health of the neighboring Everglades, support the rich marine estuaries along Florida's southwest coast. Protecting over 729,000 acres of this vast swamp, Big Cypress National Preserve contains a mixture of tropical and temperate plant communities that are home to a diversity of wildlife, including the elusive Florida panther.

images.title: Florida Panther
images.altText: a Florida Panther sits in a tree
images.caption: The Florida Panther is one of the most iconic animals of Big Cypress

images.title: Alligators of Big Cypress
images.altText: Two Alligators rest on a river bank
images.caption: Two Alligators rest on a river bank

images.title: Canoeing through mangrove tunnels
images.altText: two visitors in a canoe go through mangrove tunnels on the Turner River
images.caption: Canoeing is one of the many activities you can enjoy in Big Cypress

images.altText: A prairie foreground with tall pine trees in the background. A large blue sky with white cloud
images.caption: large open expanses of prairie bordered by pine lands create stunning landscapes

images.title: Sunrise in Big Cypress
images.altText: palm trees emerge out of the fog in an orange sunrise
images.caption: palm trees emerge out of the fog as an orange sunrise dots the landscape

description: On August 9, 1877 gun shots shattered a chilly dawn on a sleeping camp of Nez Perce. By the time the smoke cleared on August 10, almost 90 Nez Perce were dead along with 31 soldiers and volunteers. Big Hole National Battlefield was created to honor all who were there.

images.title: Battlefield at Dawn
images.altText: Multiple tepee poles and a river are silhouetted against a dawn sky.
images.caption: Today tepee poles stand sentinel at the site of August 9th, 1877 dawn attack at the Big Hole.

images.title: Camas Blooms Near the Nez Perce Camp at the Big Hole
images.altText: Blue camas flowers dot a green field with tepee poles in the background.
images.caption: The Nez Perce chose their camp site in the Big Hole in part due to the Camas, whose roots they gathered prior to the August 9th attack.

images.title: Mountain Howitzer at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.altText: a cannon overlooks a valley and distant mountains
images.caption: Nez Perce warriors captured and dismantled the Mountain Howitzer cannon before the US army could use it effectively at the Battle of the Big Hole.

images.title: Monument to the US Soldiers and Volunteers at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.altText: cross country skis rest against a large granite monument on a snowy day.
images.caption: In 1883 the United States Government erected this monument in honor of the soldiers and volunteers that served and died at the 1877 Battle of the Big Hole.

images.title: Chief Joseph Memorial at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.altText: Stone carving of a Nez Perce Warrior's head in full regalia.
images.caption: This monument, erected on the Big Hole Battlefield in 1928, reads; "To the everlasting memory of the brave warriors Chief Joseph's Band who fought on these grounds in the Nez Perce War of 1877."

images.title: Bear Paw Battlefield
images.altText: Three large stone monuments and four interpretive signs overlook a series of low hills.

fullName: Big South Fork National River & Recreation Area
description: Encompassing 125,000 acres of the Cumberland Plateau, Big South Fork National River and Recreation Area protects the free-flowing Big South Fork of the Cumberland River and its tributaries. The area boasts miles of scenic gorges and sandstone bluffs, is rich with natural and historic features and has been developed to provide visitors with a wide range of outdoor recreational activities.

images.title: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall
images.altText: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall
images.caption: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall

description: Life of all types abounds in the Big Thicket. This national preserve protects the incredible diversity of life found where multiple habitats converge in southeast Texas. Hiking trails and waterways meander through nine different ecosystems, from longleaf pine forests to cypress-lined bayous. It is a place of discovery, a place to wander and explore, a place to marvel at the richness of nature.

images.title: Big Thicket Swamp
images.altText: green swamp with cypress trees, cypress knees, palmetto, and a thick canopy
images.caption: Cypress swamp in the Lance Rosier Unit

images.title: Cypress Tree Trunks

images.title: Pitcher Plants

images.caption: Look for carnivorous pitcher plants in bogs along the Sundew Trail and Pitcher Plant Trail.

images.title: Lance Rosier Swamp

images.caption: The Big Thicket is home to large swamps, full of bald cypress trees and knees.

images.caption: See the Big Thicket by kayak or canoe

images.caption: Knobby knees, extensions of the root system, are a distinctive feature of the bald cypress trees.

images.caption: The view from the bridge over Village Creek is a highlight for hikers on the Kirby Nature Trail.

images.caption: Dwarf palmettos grow in the Big Thicket's palmetto hardwood flats.

images.caption: Small wooden bridges guide hikers across waterways on the Kirby Nature Trail.

description: The vast, wild landscape of Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area offers visitors unparalleled opportunities to immerse themselves in the natural world, and experience the wonders of this extraordinary place. With over 120,000 acres, one can find an astounding diversity in ecosystems, wildlife, and more than 10,000 years of human history to explore.

images.altText: Summer view of the Yellowtail Dam from the Ok-A-Beh road.
images.caption: Summer view of the Yellowtail Dam from the Ok-A-Beh road. (Fort Smith, MT District)

description: In 1963, images of snarling police dogs unleashed against non-violent protesters and of children being sprayed with high-pressure hoses appeared in print and television news around the world. These dramatic scenes of violent police aggression against civil rights protesters in Birmingham, Alabama were vivid examples of segregation and racial injustice in America.

images.title: Mural Sculpture of the four little girls
images.altText: 4 separate statues of the four little girls who were killed in the 16th st Baptist Church bombing
images.caption: Hundreds of people visit Kelly Ingram Park each year to learn about the Civil Rights Movement in Birmingham

images.title: Kelly Ingram Park foot soldiers statue
images.altText: Statue of a boy being grabbed by a policemen who is holding a dog posed to bite on a leash
images.caption: Statue in Kelly Ingram park dedicated to Birmingham Foot soldiers

images.title: 16th St. Baptist Church
images.altText: Colored Photo of the front of the 16th St. Baptist Church
images.caption: Hundreds of people visit Birmingham each year to see the 16th St. Baptist Church and learn about its important role in Birmingham's Civil Rights Movement

description: Within sight of downtown Miami, yet worlds away, Biscayne protects a rare combination of aquamarine waters, emerald islands, and fish-bejeweled coral reefs. Here too is evidence of 10,000 years of human history, from pirates and shipwrecks to pineapple farmers and presidents. Outdoors enthusiasts can boat, snorkel, camp, watch wildlife…or simply relax in a rocking chair gazing out over the bay.

images.title: Boca Chita Key
images.altText: Downtown Miami in background.
images.caption: Boca Chita Key is the park's most popular island destination.

images.title: Coral Reef
images.altText: The coral reefs are located mostly on the Eastern side of the park.
images.caption: Biscayne National Park is 95% water.

images.title: Green sea turtle
images.altText: Green sea turtle
images.caption: Loggerhead, Green and Hawksbill turtles are all commonly observed in park waters.

images.title: Totten Key
images.altText: Aerial view of Totten Key.
images.caption: Biscayne National Park includes the northernmost Florida Keys.

images.title: Snorkeling
images.altText: snorkeling is an easy-to-learn skill
images.caption: Experience the park's shallow reefs up close and personal by snorkeling with some of the park's most colorful wildlife.

fullName: Black Canyon Of The Gunnison National Park
description: Big enough to be overwhelming, still intimate enough to feel the pulse of time, Black Canyon of the Gunnison exposes you to some of the steepest cliffs, oldest rock, and craggiest spires in North America. With two million years to work, the Gunnison River, along with the forces of weathering, has sculpted this vertical wilderness of rock, water, and sky.

images.title: Black Canyon near Tomichi Point
images.altText: Black Canyon near Tomichi Point
images.caption: Black Canyon near Tomichi Point

images.title: Black Canyon near Painted Wall
images.altText: Black Canyon near Painted Wall
images.caption: Black Canyon near Painted Wall

fullName: Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park
description: The Blackstone River powered America's entry into the Age of Industry. The success of Samuel Slater's cotton spinning mill in Pawtucket, RI touched off a chain reaction that changed how people worked and where they lived, and continues to reverberate across the nation to this day. Come visit and see how this revolution transformed the landscape of the Blackstone Valley and then the United States.

images.title: Ashton Kelly House and canal
images.altText: Blackstone canal outside of the Wilbur Kelly House
images.caption: The Blackstone Canal and towpath along the Wilbur Kelly House in Ashton, RI

images.title: Little Red Shop

images.caption: The Little Red Shop in Hopedale, MA - the original home of the Draper Loom Corporation

images.title: Slatersville
images.altText: Slatersville
images.caption: View of John Slater's home in Slatersville, RI

images.caption: The machine shop inside the Wilkinson Mill

images.altText: Autumn in the Blackstone Valley
images.caption: Autumn in the Blackstone Valley

description: The Blue Ridge National Heritage Area is a place unlike any other on Earth, where ancient landscapes enchant the eye and age-old traditions warm the heart. The distinctive landscape of the North Carolina mountains and foothills combined with the region’s living traditions of craft, music, agriculture and Cherokee heritage create a wealth of natural and cultural treasures unmatched in our country.

images.title: Southeast Region NHA
images.altText: Southeast Region NHA
images.caption: Southeast Region NHA

description: A Blue Ridge Parkway experience is unlike any other: a slow-paced and relaxing drive revealing stunning long-range vistas and close-up views of the rugged mountains and pastoral landscapes of the Appalachian Highlands. The Parkway meanders for 469 miles, protecting a diversity of plants and animals, and providing opportunities for enjoying all that makes this region of the country so special.

images.title: Black Bear Club
images.altText: Black Bear Cub
images.caption: Black bears are among the many mammals found across the Blue Ridge Parkway.

images.title: Linn Cove Viaduct
images.altText: Fall at Linn Cove Viaduct
images.caption: Linn Cove Viaduct, located in the North Carolina Highlands district, is one of the most iconic features of the Blue Ridge Parkway

images.title: Mabry Mill
images.altText: Summer colors at Mabry Mill
images.caption: Located in Virginia's Plateau district, picturesque Mabry Mill is one of the most iconic features of the Blue Ridge Parkway

images.title: Mountain vista
images.altText: Mountain vista and clouds on the Blue Ridge Parkway
images.caption: Beautiful mountain in North Carolina draw visitors from around the world to the Blue Ridge Parkway

images.title: Linville Falls
images.altText: water cascading into Linville Falls plunge basin
images.caption: The Linville Gorge offers visitors the opportunity to learn about fascinating geology and view magnificent waterfalls.
